First step is to load the training data and labels that are used to mark anomalies.

```{r}
data <- read.csv(file="../data/train_data.csv", header=TRUE, sep=",", row.names=NULL)
data_frame <- data.frame(data)
getType <- function(x) {
  if (x['category'] == 'normal') {
    return('normal');
  } else if (x['category'] == 'smurf' || x['category'] == 'neptune') {
    return('ddos')
  } else {
    return('anomaly')
  }
}
data_frame$type <- apply(data_frame, 1, getType)
```

We want to compare how does value distribution look like for three categories - normal, ddos, anomaly.
We make a bar chart out of data.

```{r}
numeric_column_names <- names(which(sapply(data_frame ,is.numeric)))
for (column_name in numeric_column_names) {
  print(ggplot(data_frame, aes_string(column_name, fill = 'type')) + geom_density(aes(y=..scaled..), alpha = 0.5))
}
```
